chapterInfo.subject: social science
chapterInfo.chapterName: Unity in Diversity, or 'Many in the One'

questions.question: What are basic food grains like rice, wheat, and millets called because they are the basic food for most Indians?
options: Specialty grains
Imported grains
Staple grains
Cash crops
questions.explanation: The text identifies cereals and pulses as 'staple grains' because they form the basic food for most people in India.

questions.question: Which of these is mentioned as a famous type of silk sari?
options: Chintz
Khadi
Kanjivaram
Denim
questions.explanation: The text lists Banarasi, Kanjivaram, Paithani, and Patan Patola among the famous types of silk saris.

questions.question: What is the name of the collection of stories with animal characters that teaches life skills and is at least 2,200 years old?
options: The Ramayana
The Mahabharata
The Vedas
The Panchatantra
questions.explanation: The Panchatantra is described as a collection of delightful stories with animals as main characters, with an original Sanskrit text at least 2,200 years old.

questions.question: What event does the festival of Makara Sankranti and its regional variations like Pongal and Lohri mark?
options: The beginning of monsoon
The beginning of the harvest season
The new year
A historical battle
questions.explanation: The chapter states that Makara Sankranti marks the beginning of the harvest season in many parts of India.

questions.question: Which national organization conducted the massive 'People of India project' survey?
options: The Archaeological Survey of India
The National Museum
The Anthropological Survey of India
The Ministry of Culture
questions.explanation: The text mentions that the Anthropological Survey of India conducted a massive survey called the 'People of India project'.

questions.question: What are the two major epics of India that have been adapted into countless versions across the country?
options: Panchatantra and Jataka Tales
Vedas and Upanishads
Ramayana and Mahabharata
Gita and Puranas
questions.explanation: The text identifies the Ramayana and the Mahabharata as India's two epics that are central to its literary unity in diversity.

questions.question: Which type of Indian printed cotton became so popular in 17th-century Europe that its import was eventually banned by England and France?
options: Muslin
Chintz
Silk
Kalamkari
questions.explanation: The text describes 'chintz' as a beautiful type of printed cotton that became so popular in Europe that its import was banned to protect local products.

questions.question: According to the map in the chapter, what is the harvest festival celebrated in Gujarat around January 14th called?
options: Lohri
Pongal
Uttarayan
Magh Bihu
questions.explanation: The map showing different harvest festivals labels the one in Gujarat as Uttarayan.

questions.question: In the Ramayana, who kidnaps Sita, leading to the epic's central conflict?
options: Duryodhana
Krishna
Hanuman
Ravana
questions.explanation: The summary of the Ramayana mentions that Rama defeats the demon Ravana, who had kidnapped his wife Sita.

questions.question: What is the common theme shared by various kinds of dals, rice, wheat, and millets in Indian cuisine?
options: They are all imported.
They are all used only for festivals.
They are all staple grains common to almost every part of the country.
They are all grown in the same state.
questions.explanation: The text explains that despite the diversity of dishes, these food grains are common to almost every part of the country, showing unity.

questions.question: How does the sari serve as an example of 'unity in diversity'?
options: It is always made of the same fabric and worn the same way.
It is a single, common dress (unity) that comes in hundreds of fabrics, designs, and draping styles (diversity).
Only one community in India wears the sari.
The sari has not changed at all for thousands of years.
questions.explanation: The text explains that the sari is a single dress (unity) but has immense variety in fabrics, weaving, color, and ways of wearing (diversity).

questions.question: What did the 'People of India project' conclude about the Ramayana and Mahabharata's presence in India?
options: They are only known in North India.
They are only read in Sanskrit.
Many communities, including tribal ones, have their own versions and connect their history to the epics.
The stories are no longer popular.
questions.explanation: The project found that many communities, including tribes like the Bhils and Gonds, have their own versions and legends connecting their regions to the epics' heroes.

questions.question: Why did England and France ban the import of Indian chintz in the 17th century?
options: The fabric was of poor quality.
They wanted to protect their own textile products from the competition.
There was a dispute over shipping routes.
Indian merchants refused to trade with them.
questions.explanation: The text states that to protect their own products from a sharp drop in sales, England and France decided to ban the import of chintz.

questions.question: What commonality is observed among festivals like Maghi/Lohri, Pongal, Poush Songkranti, and Magh Bihu?
options: They are all celebrated in the same state.
They are all different names for similar harvest festivals celebrated around the same time.
They all involve flying kites.
They are celebrated in honor of the same historical king.
questions.explanation: The chapter uses these festivals as an example of a common theme (harvest) celebrated across India at the same time but with different names and customs.

questions.question: The stories of the Panchatantra were adapted into about 200 versions in over 50 languages worldwide. What does this illustrate?
options: That the original text was lost.
That Indian literature was not very original.
How a single source of stories ('one') can spread and transform into many different versions ('many').
That animals can't really talk.
questions.explanation: The text uses the global spread and adaptation of the Panchatantra to illustrate how 'one' collection of stories has become 'many'.

questions.question: The text says 'the same ingredients (unity) can be used in a number of combinations (diversity) to prepare an endless variety of dishes!' What does this analogy explain?
options: That all Indian food tastes the same.
That India has a limited number of spices.
The concept of 'unity in diversity' as applied to Indian cuisine.
That cooking is a difficult skill.
questions.explanation: This sentence is a direct analogy explaining the principle of unity in diversity using the example of food, where common ingredients create diverse dishes.

questions.question: According to the text, what is the first thing that usually strikes visitors about India?
options: Its political system
Its uniform culture
Its rich diversity
Its economic policies
questions.explanation: The chapter begins by stating that India's rich diversity is usually the first thing that strikes visitors.

questions.question: What is the central theme of both the Ramayana and the Mahabharata?
options: A travelogue to different cities
The creation of the universe
Heroes fighting to re-establish dharma
A guide to ancient farming techniques
questions.explanation: The text states that these two epics narrate the stories of heroes who fight to re-establish dharma (what is right).

questions.question: The chapter shows multiple images of a sari being used for purposes other than a dress, such as a cradle or a fishing net. What does this demonstrate?
options: That saris are not good as dresses.
That people in the past were not fashionable.
The simplicity, economy, and creative versatility of the garment.
That there is a shortage of rope and nets.
questions.explanation: These images illustrate the point made in the text about the sari's simplicity, economy, and the diverse, creative ways it can be used beyond clothing.

questions.question: According to historian Vincent Smith, what provides the answer to the challenge of writing a single history for a bewilderingly diverse country like India?
options: Focusing only on the history of its rulers
Ignoring the diversity altogether
The fact that India offers unity in diversity
Writing separate histories for every community
questions.explanation: The text quotes Vincent Smith, who found the answer to the query in the fact that 'India offers unity in diversity'.

questions.question: Sri Aurobindo's quote mentions 'Swabhava and Swadharma' as the sure foundation for India. Based on the chapter's theme, what does this likely imply?
options: India should adopt a single, uniform culture.
India's true nature (Swabhava) is to find its own path (Swadharma) through the principle of unity in diversity.
India should isolate itself from the rest of the world.
India's foundation is based on economic principles alone.
questions.explanation: In the context of 'Many in the One', Swabhava (one's own true nature) and Swadharma (one's own way) suggest that India's strength lies in embracing its inherent nature of unity in diversity, not in imposing uniformity.

questions.question: Jawaharlal Nehru observed that even illiterate villagers knew hundreds of verses from the epics by heart. What does this suggest about the role of these texts in Indian society?
options: Literacy was not valued in ancient India.
The epics were only for entertainment and had no moral value.
The cultural and moral content of the epics was deeply integrated into the popular mind through a strong oral tradition, transcending literacy.
Only villagers were interested in the epics.
questions.explanation: Nehru's observation highlights that the epics were not just written texts for the elite, but a living part of the culture, transmitted orally and providing a shared moral and narrative framework for all.

questions.question: The text states, 'Indian culture celebrates diversity as an enrichment, but never loses sight of the underlying unity'. How do the examples of the epics support this?
options: There is only one official version of each epic.
The core story and values (unity) remain recognizable across countless regional and folk variations (diversity).
The epics are always performed in the same language, Sanskrit.
Different communities are forbidden from adapting the epics.
questions.explanation: The epics' core themes, characters, and moral questions provide an underlying unity, which is enriched and nourished by the diverse ways different communities retell and interpret the stories.

questions.question: The 'People of India' project found 325 languages using 25 scripts. How does this finding present a challenge to the idea of a single, unified national identity?
options: It proves that no unity exists in India.
It suggests that a unified identity must be based on something other than a single language or script, embracing linguistic diversity instead.
It means communication between different parts of India is impossible.
It shows that only 25 languages are important.
questions.explanation: This 'bewildering diversity,' as Vincent Smith called it, means that any concept of Indian unity cannot be based on linguistic uniformity. Instead, it must be a unity that accommodates and thrives on this diversity.

questions.question: Why would tribal communities like the Bhils and Gonds adapt the Mahabharata and Ramayana and connect the heroes to their own regions?
options: They were forced to do so by rulers.
To make these national narratives part of their own local history and identity, thereby participating in a shared cultural web.
They misunderstood the original stories.
There were no other stories available to them.
questions.explanation: This adaptation is an active process of cultural integration. By placing epic heroes in their own lands, communities make the national story a local one, weaving their own identity into the larger cultural tapestry of India.

questions.question: Rabindranath Tagore's prayer is to 'never lose the bliss of the touch of the one in the play of the many'. What does this sentiment advocate for?
options: Focusing only on unity and ignoring diversity.
Appreciating diverse expressions (the many) while always feeling the underlying connection or unity (the one).
The replacement of 'the many' with 'the one'.
A society where everyone is completely independent with no unifying elements.
questions.explanation: Tagore's prayer beautifully captures the essence of the chapter: finding joy and meaning in the diverse manifestations of life ('the play of the many') without losing connection to the fundamental unity that binds them.

questions.question: The chapter discusses food, clothing, festivals, and literature. What is the common analytical pattern used in all four examples?
options: Proving that diversity is a problem for India.
Demonstrating that all aspects of Indian culture originated from one place.
Identifying a common element or theme (unity) and then showing its numerous variations and expressions (diversity).
Arguing that unity is more important than diversity.
questions.explanation: In each section, the text first establishes a unifying factor (staple grains, the sari, the harvest season, the epics) and then elaborates on the rich diversity of its expression.

questions.question: The text states that in classical arts and architecture, 'both diversity and unity are easily noticeable'. Based on the chapter's logic, what might this look like?
options: All temples look exactly the same.
There are no common principles in Indian architecture.
Different regional styles of temples (diversity) might share common underlying principles of sacred geometry or iconic figures (unity).
Architecture shows unity, but art shows only diversity.
questions.explanation: Applying the chapter's logic, one would expect to find common philosophical or structural principles (unity) expressed through distinct regional architectural styles, materials, and carvings (diversity).

questions.question: The chapter mentions 'many Indians may be called migrants' because they don't live near their birthplace. How does this internal migration contribute to India's 'unity in diversity'?
options: It erases regional cultures entirely.
It prevents people from different regions from ever meeting.
It leads to the constant mixing of people, languages, and customs, reinforcing diversity in any given place while also creating shared experiences.
It forces everyone to adopt the culture of the place they move to.
questions.explanation: The movement of people across regions is a dynamic force that enhances diversity locally (e.g., a person from Bengal living in Kerala) while also fostering a broader, shared understanding and national unity through interaction.

questions.question: Why does the final sentence argue that unity 'nourishes' diversity?
options: Because unity forces everyone to be diverse.
Because without a shared cultural or civilizational foundation (unity), the various differences (diversity) might lead to fragmentation rather than a rich, interconnected tapestry.
Because diversity can only exist if it is centrally controlled.
Because unity and diversity are conflicting ideas that cannot coexist.
questions.explanation: The idea that unity 'nourishes' diversity implies a symbiotic relationship. A common foundation of values and shared heritage provides a stable ground from which diverse cultural expressions can grow and flourish without breaking the whole apart.
